Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Inside the Secret Garden of The Witchery

rLYujSyLCwhM_CaX4OpaNg.text: For a place with their reputation, the only acceptable review ought to be five stars, so the stars are theirs to lose. Thus this review will have a somewhat negative tone even though this was a very nice meal. Here are the two chief reasons I find it impossible to award them five stars: 1. The bread. It was nowhere close to the quality of bread I have had at much less reputable institutions. Is this what their mainstream clientele wants? I hope not, and thus they need to up the level of the bread significantly and it wouldn't even be difficult. 2. My daughter's scallops were served with a very nice tarragon sauce and nearly cold, unimpressive mashed potatoes. I have no problems with mashed potatoes, but even I can make better mashed potatoes, and serve it warm. (If this was truly the intention by the chef, then I guess we will just have to disagree on it being a good idea.) 3. This is a bit whiney but here we go: They were out of the vintage port wine by the glass and instead of corking up something else, they would only suggest that I go with the LBV instead. Nope. Not happening. But a True five star establishment would have opened some other bottle (or just make sure they don't run out). Having said this, here are some things they get right: 1. Very impressive wine list. 2. Very nice interior. We were in the "Secret Garden", so if there is a next time, we will try the original dining room. 3. Great (though not perfect) service. 4. My main dish of monkfish was delicious, as was the cheese plate, and the chocolate tart. So, if there is a second time, and I hope there will be, I expect them to have perfected their glitches and be a True five star experience.

hgLYOTKoZy8SkFNLjaolwg.text: Not impressed... The building is beautiful, and the staff very nice and dressed... appropriately, with long aprons, bow ties and the like.  Their wine list reads like a belgian bars beer catalogue, reaching for 1cm of thickness. Sadly, they seem to lack a chef. The food was fairly prepared, but there was no richness of flavours, nothing going on in my palate... I've had a very similar venison burger in a pub. And at least there, it fit in the bun! Not a bad experience at all, but know you are going for the quaint atmosphere, the candles, the decor, and the wines. Not so much the food....

_LurfX6Y5TyEM9icOFzlSA.text: As evidenced by the reviews here, there are some pretty high expectations for Witchery. I was no exception. I had heard a lot of great things and was hoping for the best.  First I want to say that I think this is a restaurant that really knows how to space their seatings well. I believe they have three seatings a night, like 5pm, 7pm and 9pm. Something along those lines. This ensures you have enough time for multiple courses and dont feel rushed. It also means that you need to make reservations in advance to ensure you get the time you want.  I really love the ambiance of Witchery. The darker lighting really gives it a sense of drama and the decor and staircase decent into the dining room really makes a statement. I much prefer this over a bright, stuffy, all-white restaurant. The service here is formal, but not uncomfortably so. Our server was the perfect blend of 'there when you need him', but not obtrusive.  As for the food, we decided if we were going to do it, we were going to go all out. Bottle of wine, apps, salad, entrees, desserts - the works. Sure it is on the pricier side, but there are definitely more affordable options on the menu. I also felt that in comparison to the price you get outstanding quality. My scallops were like a little piece of heaven in a beautiful shell. My dining partner ate her grilled fish v-e-r-y s-l-o-w-l-y so as to savor every bite.   Over all the combination of quality food, the intoxicating, enchanting setting, excellent service (and a good wine buzz) makes Witchery the sort of experience I crave when on vacation and I cant wait to return next time I am in Edinburgh.

P-kl4lxCHb34UpKzbJsVeQ.text: As good as it gets in terms of ambience!! I've never been in such a beautiful restaurant. This alone makes it worth the price tag, especially for a special occasion.  Or, if you are a visitor to Edinburgh, it would be a nice way to spend an evening: dining here, roaming up to the castle look off and wandering down the royal mile as the sun sets, onward to a whisky in a cozy pub. Mmm, sounds like a perfect night (or date) to me!   As good as it gets, in Edinburgh, for dining.   I'd give it the 5 stars except I've had better service at a chain restaurant. Our server seemed disingenuous. My biggest complaint is that the dude didn't know what wine would go best with scallops (which were fabulous).  At the most famous restaurant in Edinburgh, they really should school the servers on wine pairing!

8Riy8rb6z4FThNdkvpxGtg.text: I went to The Witchery with some work colleagues a couple of years ago.  I found it OK, the food was pretty good, however, I thought the service could have been better.  I have friends who have been more recently and they thought the same.  It's a shame as The Witchery has a really good reputation - seems that it isn't as consistent as it maybe should be.

OXrp7IWvZrVRyp3QYzZHrA.text: The Witchery has a cult following as the most exclusive restaurant ever, sadly the restaurant lacks style and is slowly becoming known as the place to get ripped off.  Dishes sound delicious but are decidedly mundane. Ideal if you want to spot Z list Celebs and Actors who tax evade yet make out they promote Scotland.

Ep6Duxy9_j0DKRmDqIvrMQ.text: We consider ourselves foodies and have eaten in the best restaurants in the world.  This was not one of them.  The room is beautiful, but the service was rather snippy actually.  The waiter was unconcerned with our comments about undercooked chicken, plastic in food and flavorless mash.  This was not fine dining, despite the pricing.  This was more like mediocre food served by rude wait staff in a pretty room.  All in all - meh.

FYnfDXBeIguBJ3qqKKZ2zg.text: went for lunch. had the set menu. was reasonably priced and decent food.   what made it for me was the surroundings. like eating in Henry VIII's court. chandeliers, table settings, tapestries, candles. beautiful.  a must for fine dining in edinburgh, even if its not 100% fine.

wjPHZpGTsRJ8y20QVjEZ8g.text: I think this is one of those places where its reputation has gotten ahead of what it can actually deliver.  I mean, dont get me wrong - I went for a meal with my girlfriend (who had massivly high expectations) and was, over all a bit dissapointed. My girlfriend however, was not. I have therefor come to the conclusion that the Witchery experience depends a lot on how dark a shade your Rose Tinted glasses are.  I had heard how splendid this place was, and frankly for the money I paid, didnt feel that the food was of any more high quality than other restaurants in Edinburgh who have the same reputation but charge far less. My girlfriend however, who had built this place up so much that she 'knew' how excellent the Witchery would be, claimed that everything she saw, ate and drank was 'perfect'. As I said, I do believe this place is a matter of opinion.

LkzkHhkoWSJfGAbsL1NGnA.text: Excellent food and service.  They were running a little bit late and graciously offered us a few drinks for our trouble.  Compared to a few other high end restaurants we went to on this trip, this was the best, would certainly return.

voqOccDAstQfey48r-N_ng.text: Ok, I take what I said back.  Sortof. The food is really really really good, you can't deny it, and the service is immaculate and the surroundings are amazing.   But there's still that one thing holding me back from giving it the 5*.....I still don't know what it is...something isn't quite right...

VyhCMcvaMNGydapgPwTGWw.text: The setting of the witchery is probably the most romantic place you can eat in Edinburgh. We ate in the garden room which is more airy and not as dark as the main dining room. It has large windows and high ceilings so its like eating in a tower! The staff are ok, a bit faceless and not the level you'd expect for the amount you pay to eat here. The food is gourmet and beautifully presented but I think you over pay for the quality of the food. It's nothing to get really excited about.  At Christmas the decor is more than stunning and it becomes a christmas paradise. Overall it was a lovely experience but we were not amused to be charged 4.50 for what we thought was free water!! Worth a visit.

R0djZ2MncCtsqJAgcQXLQQ.text: Review is only for the restaurant.  I won a bet and my friend took me to dinner here.  Hands down the most beautiful restaurant I've ever been to.  Decorated like a gothic castle with candles everywhere, dripping in flowers, dark wrought iron furniture.  The ambiance was amazing.  The food was pretty good.  (I'm so SPOILED being from San Francisco, where we have the best food in the world)...the salad course was fantastic.  The main dishes were good but not memorable.  The dessert was very good.  You're really going for the opportunity to eat in what seems like an 18th century dining room.  The prix-fixe menu makes it very affordable.

ooD1o1jB8Luzwa8b_8RuPw.text: We came here during our trip to Edinburgh on recommendation from a tour book. I tried to make reservations for dinner but there were no tables open until 11 pm, so I had to settle for coming during lunch.  I had their herb baked scallops with smoked Iberico pancetta and garlic, with a side of salad and mashed potatoes. The scallops were so tender and delicious. My boyfriend had the light lunch with duck egg florentine and pork sausages with a side of mashed potatoes. Initially I was worried it wouldn't be enough food, but their portions are huge.   They also have really good service. Overall a great dining experience.

M5cwcowThEg1aVPWjOH93A.text: My only regret is that I can't give this place zero stars.  Where to start?  Bad slow rude service.  Food was mediocre at best and the cost was very high.  We actually passed on The Kitchin to go here.  My wife will never hear the end of it.  Friend ordered the ribeye, I ordered the scallops, wife ordered the three little pigs.  I switched with wife when food came as I knew that she wouldn't like hers.  Ok the "3 little pigs", a lump of pig fat approx 2 inch square, uneatable, the "loin" was minuscule, and no we are not comparing to "american" portions.   The bacon was tooth breaking.  Ok so we are done with dinner, ask for the check and then wait over 20 minutes to get check.  Friend tipped, I took the money off of the table.  Worst 2hrs of my life.  Wish wish wish I could give them zero stars.

3_u2RAp8d4R8v7jh8nW1DQ.text: Awesome restaurant - just brilliant. Millybroadbent has summed it up very nicely with her description - it is a really magical place to go and visit. The venue is just superb at the foot of Edinburgh Castle and is beautifully lit to give the whole place a fabulous atmosphere.   The friendly and knowledgeable staff, brilliant food and the venue is just about as good as it gets. The wine list really is a massive book (think encyclopedia not airport novel as a size guide)...for me I had to stick to the front...but if you have the money there is an amazing choice if you go back through the book.   It's an absolute bargain if you go for a pre- or post- theatre sitting.   Can't recommend it highly enough - if you are in Edinburgh, get yourself along there. Especially if you are after a romantic setting...although it's not just for dates, it's worth a visit whoever you are with.

_ARixhg4qy0r7_W25NIfZQ.text: We went to the Witchery for a late lunch after walking around the Castle.  Heard it was one of the best restaurants in Edinburgh and it lived up to expectations.  For starter I had the assiette of charcuterie which was pretty good.  I selected the Fisherman's Pie as my main which was pretty good, not your normal heavy and creamy pie.  My friend got the lunch set menu and really liked it as well.  I also give them props b/c while other groups were there in suits, I walked in dressed like a scrub off the street (read as: underarmour...  seriously) but they still gave us respectable service (not sure I would have).  Overall a really good restaurant a nice change of pace from normal pub food at most other establishments around the city.

sOgaMy-TA5iBls0rPUIonw.text: Wandered in underdressed. Felt very out of place. Got the 2 course lunch for 15. (not a bad deal for a fancy restaurant). Pea ham. Fish pie. Very delicious. It's fine dining meets Scottish food. I also ordered a couple of oysters, and they didn't disappoint.

WMddgCQe4Y8cAetLrPf0og.text: It was a pampering experience but unless money is no object I wouldn't go for the food, which was fine but unremarkable. My hot smoked salmon would have passed for mediocre wedding food. The beef tartare appetizer was fine. The fudge that came with the coffee was meltingly delicious and they seem to do bottomless coffee so if you have the chutzpah to come and enjoy the ambience and unlimited coffee with fudge for 5.95, you have all my support! Otherwise I think that the average diner for whom a restaurant with these price points is an extravagant treat is mainly paying for the maintenance of an extensive wine list you mostly can't afford anyway. I recommend the Northbridge Brasserie (at the Scotsman Hotel) for a luxurious meal that will be delicious in proportion to cost.

xKNWN7p0-3FMlekZwZE-gQ.text: I have heard so many things about The Witchery and although it is near the castle, I was hoping that they have not fallen into the category where they charge extortionate tourist price for mediocre food quality.  Unfortunately, they have.    I ordered the steak tartare as the starter.  Presentation was great but I thought it lacked seasoning.  Of all the steak tartare I have eaten so far in Edinburgh, this has by far the least ingredients and seasoning.  I also felt it was a bit dry too.  This was priced at 12.50 and I do think that you can get a better steak tartare starter elsewhere for a cheaper price.  I had the Seabass as the main.  I have a picture and if you see the size of the fish, it is just too small to justify its price at 28.  The presentation - great but again taste was very bland. The fish was also not de-scaled properly and from the picture you can see 2 scales still left on the skin of the fish.  I eat a lot of fish and from the smell and taste, the fish was not that fresh at all.  I have been to its sister restaurant at The Tower and you get a whole seabass for the same price and it was the best seabass with brown shrimp I have ever eaten in Edinburgh.  This is just a plain rip off.  Creme Brulee as the dessert priced at 7.50.  From my picture, the portion is great and worth it but unfortunately, it came out as thick custard and not a consistency of a real creme brulee.  One of the lowest ranked creme brulee in Edinburgh for me.  The highlight of the whole experience for me was the mango sorbet that came together with the creme brulee.  However, the creme brulee was not sweet enough that when you return to eating the creme brulee, it just tasted even more bland.  Unfortunately, I have to rate this well known restaurant 2 stars - one star for ambiance and another for its service.  Sure, if you want to pay for the decor, ambiance and service this is the place to be to impress.  However, the quality of food and certainly its value for money has failed to impress me.  At a price I have paid here, I would rather spend my money at The Tower or a Michelin star restaurant.  Sorry Witchery, you have to do better.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Creme Brulee
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Seabass - small portion for price
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Steak Tartare - bland

yqpfBtJGxvJsk3Ka2x5UDw.text: The environment is amazing, one of the most beautiful restaurants I have ever been. The food is fine, nothing special. However the staff is rude and slow, one of the worst food experiences I have had to date. Considering the price and reputation, I would expect far more. If you're okay with being treated like trash and waiting 45 minutes+ for each course, then I would recommend.

zEYPk74yhHwMOOWoLbbjSw.text: For the price, this place is astoundingly average. I didn't feel like anything I was was particularly amazing or worth the cost. I brought my mom here when she came to visit me hoping to wow her but she felt the same. What you're really paying for is the experience and the history of the building- which is fine. Just don't come here expecting incredible dishes. The service was also really spotty. It's a pretty fancy place so maybe we just weren't classy enough but it just felt very snooty and I felt bad asking for anything. Took ages to flag anyone down. The maitre d' was the highlight of the evening and told us about the history of the place and his own story. He was very friendly and one of the reasons the night was a success. The other is the fantastic atmosphere- it's definitely a picturesque place. Maybe stick to drinks.

Q-YJYZYh-M-IYPHnKGormg.text: We were really looking forward to this meal. The room is so tiny compared to what is on the website - you are eating with your neighbors! The food was good, not great! Huge wine selection! The service was rushed, i found our waitress pushing to the extent it was annoying. She did not get it.

CXxBeQkOi-_NXMXce3WaqA.text: It's taken me a while to write a review about our stay at the Witchery, only because we've stayed here more than once and this time it was a bit different.  It was over Hogmanay, we checked in for a three nights stay and have managed to check into a different suite every time we go, we're working our way through each of the suites.  I was a bit taken back by what I experienced this time around, the staff were great as usual, rooms were spotless and fully stocked with all the goodies that come with it, however, I felt a very strange something there, I cannot explain it, just out of the norm and out of anything I can explain.  Spooked would be putting it lightly. Would I go back, you bet!  Would I stay in the same room, no.  I'm not a ghost hunter, not into any hocus pocus stuff but I have to say this has taken me to an entirely new view on this place and it's history.

zEW5DrrjpRtkVkZr_tJtuA.text: The steaks were absolutely phenomenal - it was extremely pricey, but we knew that before we made our reservation - and honestly, it was a really nice treat.  Food was great, service was excellent - we were in the Secret Garden dining room - my only complaint was the lack of lighting.  Candlelit dining rooms are great - but you couldn't see anything of the amazing room / decorations.  Highlights were the scallop appetizer and the filet main course.  Delicious!

UKfEPR1wHXPBquwCa5YOfg.text: The place is very nice!the decoration is great.The menu looks appetizing.However,the service is HORRIBLE! They served the butter ,then the cold bread at least 20 minutes later. We ordered a honey truffle goat cheese that came without the truffle neither the honey! We waited around 20 min after appetizers and when we complained that the main course was not served yet,the manager approached our table to say that the computer is saying that its only been a 10 minutes wait and when we argued that it has been more and if its going to take much more time then we d rather cancel ,he said that if we r unhappy we can leave. Too bad such a great place is ran by an unprofessional staff.

tdvwt4M7WU6iMyLGLuJUkg.text: I realized there was a gap in my hotel stays between here and Dublin, so decided to stay on an extra day in Edinburgh.  I have to say that The Witchery was symbolic of this decision. It was wonderful from end to end.  While yes a bit expensive, it was the full treatment for all of this.  I had fois gras, venison, the pudding assortment and matching whiskies and wines - every bit was worth it, delightful, delicious. The location implies tourist trade, but hell, I'm a tourist, and I've eaten at many fine places around the map, and this was up there.

gN-qAg1HbZI2WP9mJ2IylQ.text: I researched recommendations for local cuisine pre Edinburgh visit but made the mistake of not calling around for reservations until the night before. The Witchery was the only spot with availability. Service, if not exactly friendly, was the best of any restaurant I visited in Edinburgh. With that said, waters were not refilled and specials, if they had them, were not mentioned. Wine and food menus were delivered promptly. Romantic atmosphere. We ordered wine and I asked for Ketel on the rocks with an olive and a side of club soda, which made the waiter  look at me like I had two heads.  "I'll ask at the bar," he said, his expression dubious. Like they don't have vodka and soda at the bar? Yea right. The head waiter stopped by to double check my order and then finally brought out all our drinks.  Overlooking the slow start, we ordered the Roasted Arran Beet Salad and Haggis, neeps and tatties for some local flavor. The Haggis turned out to be one smooth tennis ball sized lump of mystery meat on a bed of mashed turnips and potato. Turnips were delicious but I could only stomach a few nibbles of the meat turd and at $14 this was a pricey experiment. The Aran beets were beautifully plated but a tiny portion. For mains, we had the scallops with bacon and leek soup and Wild Mushroom Risotto. The soup was a hit bu the risotto was incredibly bland. Scallops were served with the bright orange foot attached which we thought was an odd presentation though both taste and texture were delectable. The mashed potatos had a ton of cream and butter so tasted great. The lettuce leaves in the side salad had long red stems attached which was super annoying.  We did not get desert. Overall I was underwhelmed. I don't think the food warrant the prices. You are paying heavily for atmosphere and I personally for one didn't think it was worth it.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Scallops
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Leek Soup &amp; Roasted Arran beets katie rogers

zWMYLc1o73N2AbsGahEFPA.text: Loved the ambience and intricate details of the restaurant. Great wine selection. Meals well prepared. Prompt service except when getting the check, waited 20minutes after notifying waiter that we have eaten dessert and plates were cleared. However, I've noticed this trend in many restaurants in the UK. Only oversight in our meal was the truffle honey beetroots with goat curd, was missing the goat curd. It was just beets on a plate. However, I love beets so it didn't bother me. I had the ribeye with bordelaise sauce and for dessert, the creme brulee which was perfectly prepared and well worth the wait. I suggest getting it with the ice cream rolled in Cocoa. Overall, it was a wonderful experience and I would easily go back!

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

iLDgdUtpETx35-gNdlUMVw.text: We were walking along the Royal Mile after the Edinburgh castle and decided to check this place out. We clearly didn't make reservations, but the nice lady at the reception found us a table at their front restaurant. The ambiance is  amazing and this is definitely an occasion place. I ordered the honey truffle goat cheese and a dessert. Both tasted good, however, I'd only go back to enjoy the ambiance if I were to.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

hQAiGYqf2Tg3FTbjPSus6w.text: We had the three course meal at this place. The lamb was delicious but I think the natural smell of lamb could have been removed more. The red mullet was fantastic. The carrot cake was average. The service could be better: we were assigned a corner seat where our waiter kept ignoring us.

9na2Y2eZb39oKEF6zpkYOg.text: Visiting Scotland with a friend on the week when their Michelin star restaurant near our hotel was closed for holidays, we found a recommendation for the Witchery in our hotel room guide, checked it out online, and made a late online reservation.    The ambiance was amazing: the entire dining room was lit only by candlelight, with (what appeared to be) antique sculptures separating some of the center room dining tables.    The service was good.  Our food was lovely - not the best I have had (I am quite fussy and live in NYC so am admittedly a harsher critique than most), but it was very good.    The Witchery is clearly a local "special occasion" restaurant, full of polite and lovely patrons. We had drinks and wine and a couple courses, and our dinner came to around $250.  You will need to make a reservation.   I would visit again.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The Witchery

rXWwoPoCA-VSiZuOYk053Q.text: Food was ok, but nothing to write home about.  Service was absent and forgetful.  For example: I order tea with my desert.  10 minutes later I get milk and sugar.  Then my desert comes... but I still don't have tea... just cream n sugar.  When I spend 150 pounds I expect more.

rfl72r1Z1iHJ3ghtr3x9VA.text: We went to The Witchery per the recommendation of a friend local to the area. I made my reservation in advance as advised which was good as the main seating area has around 15-20 tables. The interior is decorated beautifully with rich colours and candles. The entrance is just off the main road. The restaurant has two seating areas- the main witchery area and the secret garden. The secret garden has a separate seating area which can be accessed via a private pathway. Each seating area requires a separate reservation.   In terms of food our table ordered off the a-la-carte menu. My fellow diners thoroughly enjoyed their choices! The first ordered the lobster bisque to start and the halibut for their main and the second ordered the oysters to start and the venison for their main. They both commentated that their food was 5 stars and very flavoursome. I ordered the honey beetroot truffle with goat's cheese to start and the vegetarian moussaka as my main. The vegetarian food was ok but was a bit lacking for me. My starter arrived with the tinest piece of goat's cheese on it- for this to truly count as an ingredient it needs to be more present in the dish.  My moussaka though good- was more like a ratatouille just to manage expectations. We three shared a mashed potato and greens on the side which were both good. For dessert- we ordered Creme brulee and the chocolate tart with orange marmalade ice cream. The Creme brulee was absolutely amazing but I would pass on the chocolate tarte with organge marmalade ice cream. I only ordered it as the ice cream sounded unique and I love chocolate and orange combinations but the ice-cream did not taste orange to me at all.  We also ordered tea's which come with an assortment of small cookies and pieces of fudge. The tea's are Twinning's though...I think it would have been nicer to have had loose tea in a restaurant of this calibre and for 4.50 a tea pot- I felt I was paying more for the small shortbread cookies and pieces of fudge than the tea which I had wanted more. The service was good but needed to be slowed down a bit. They were extremely attentive - but at one point I was asked by 3 different people in the course of 2 minutes if my food was ok when it had just been served. Still- the servers were very polite and very nice. The service just needs to be slowed down a bit as I say.  Overall- I would return as was a very unique experience with beautiful ambiance. Next time-I will book a spot in the secret garden dining area for dinner as it looks a bit quieter and the entrance is all lite up beautifully at night with lights lining the pathway.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Beautiful entrance to the secret garden seating area
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Honey beetroot salad with goat&#39;s cheese (can you spot the goat cheese....)
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. My friends mains- halibut and venison.

LYinmuiXfnlvKbMYk5nb7g.text: One of the most unique places I have been and wonderful food. I was here in late December for a wedding reception. The location was stunning! We had the lower dining room, which was decorated beautifully! The food and wine were wonderful. The corn soup with guinea fowl was delicious. I completely recommend this spot!

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

26m43Lw67rNmtdQLZu-6Hg.text: My wife and I were in Edinburgh for our honeymoon, spied this place just outside the Ediburgh castle gate at the start of the Royal Mile, and thought it might be a nice lunch stop, but despite the fact that my bride was wearing a very Witch-y Griffindor sweatshirt, the perfectly genteel captain informed us (with a most credible impersonation of cordial regret) that every table in the completely empty restaurant we beheld was, in fact, reserved for a lunch crowd which would be descending like a plague of locusts at any moment, and remaining until 3 p.m. at least.   I strongly suspect that there were simply "no tables available" for people dressed like tourists. So, if you ever go to Edinburgh, do me a favor: send a telegram weeks in advance requesting their very best table, get a written confirmation from the manager, then show up wearing sandals, shorts, and pit-stained American flag t-shirts and dragging large back packs, shopping bags, and duffles, tell them you wired ahead for a reservation and show them your confirmation letter, then ask if they have a kayak check.  El Rauncho Grande

rVi7bMt3p6S-mSWkPFx4aA.text: Was impressed with how the place looked. Got taken to our table and the waitress sat us down and gave us some butter and brought us  a bottle of water on request, no bread for like 10 minutes but at least we had the butter to look at and water to drink, then we looked at our menu decided what to eat and then the wait  started........ menus were shut and it seemed to take for ever for someone to come over and take our order. The waitress looked and acted like she was in a bad mood and that made me and my partner feel a little uncomfortable but as the night went on and the food started coming out it started getting better. The waitress mood lifted and we went on to have a good night of food and drink. The bill was not as expensive as we thought so all in all a good night.  Its not a 5 star place but good at making you feel like your in a top restaurant. Defo recommend. The bill came to 150. 3 courses x2 , 2 cokes, bottle water, 2 ports and 2 coffees.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

0toEEP_YPeCvMe2pcVcNJA.text: What's great: - The atmosphere and decor is amazing.  We ate down in the Secret Garden (it's the same restaurant, just a different room).  It was dark, candle-lit, and very romantic.  Tons of amazing stuff to look at. - The location is ideal.  It's just steps from the castle, Whisky Experience, and Camera Obscura.  It's really easy to see sights, then have a nice dinner right there.  What's okay: - The food was uninspired.  It was okay, but we feel it didn't quite measure up to the ambiance and price.  For example, I was expecting something amazing from the flat iron steak, but the cut wasn't that tender and the flavor was pretty basic. - The service was uneven.  Some of the staff were very friendly and casual, and others (including our waiter) seemed competent, but a bit stiff.  Conclusion: If you want a fancy, romantic dinner in Edinburgh, and you're not a foodie, I don't think you will really go wrong with The Witchery - but you'll pay for it.

knAmKrlz1OVoo_LP1oJLBA.text: Was prepared for a tourist trap but pleasantly surprised by the INCREDIBLE food, service and ambiance. We ate in the Secret Garden and had grilled octopus and haggis for starters followed by the three course meal (38 pounds, worth it for the portions and variety).

6hFQSf_dzKh-lf51sXOBSQ.text: The most favorable part of the experience was walking up the Royal Mile and seeing the Castle and the beautiful exterior of the Witchery. However all hope would be quickly abandoned.  Upon entering it became apparent quickly that we had been caught in an inglorious tourist trap and a very expensive one at that.  The restaurant itself is beautiful and the potential is immense, however the food would be better at any Hard Rock Cafe and for a fraction of the price.  The staff were friendly but there seemed to be a sense of confusion around the restaurant. At the end of the day the food matters more than the ambience and this place is a total failure.

k5-7Pq4nEpQlXt8nnRItdQ.text: We went here for dinner and it seems as though it can be a mixed bag. For some people it is lovely and for others it was a disappointment.   We very much enjoyed our dinner here. The setting is lovely and we found the food to be quite good.  We got the price fix menu which was a wonderful soup to start, lasagna for dinner and dessert.  I deducted a star from the review for the desert which was rather bland and tasteless graham crackers. The presentation was nice, but it was a miss on flavor.  The service was very nice and we overall really enjoyed our meal here.  As a note, we felt very under dressed here in jeans. We had been traveling for most of the day and while I am not sure if there is a stated dress code I might suggest more formal attire.

zjFyC85kuwbaQEfhUxVAJQ.text: Maybe I am not a "fancy food" person so take my review with a grain of salt.  The ambiance was exceptional. Candle lit only and a really neat "hidden" entrance. The servers were very attentive and know the menu.   The food...it was ok. The scallop app was mediocre and you only get three. The main courses we had were the duck and the steak. Both were cooked exactly how we asked but hind sight we should have asked for the steak to be mid-rare. Medium was too much. Flavors were average. You are lying for the atmosphere and service more than the food.  The dessert sampler and cheese plate are both very good.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

18oD9O2YIaT2Vjo0aNVgAA.text: Excellent late afternoon tea! We had our tea a bit later as other guests were having their early dinners. The tea was rich and beautiful and the finger sandwiches, cakes and scones were each an extreme delight. It was quite a lot of food for my husband and I, so we ended up skipping a full dinner. The tapestry lined walls and decor were really cool, I loved the feeling of the space. Waiters were attentive but at a distance which I liked. Get high tea here!

_--lYiXjfHVwg0PRm7ZSZQ.text: Wanted to go somewhere on our last night and it was not worth the money for the portion that you get. Spent way too much $ here for nothing. Better off at a pub. Would not recommend.

GtXu9G8kSmzJjVZ4YejOEA.text: The ambience of the Witchery is amazing-the history is so dark.  The dining room is lit by candles only.  We were very disappointed with the ribeye steak.  For 39 pounds, one would expect a quality cut.  It was a supermarket cut steak that was difficult to cut with the steak knife, and was thin and chewy.  We should have sent it back.  My fish was excellent as was the scallops I ordered for an appetizer.

PP7BW3aUI4VZxsBCsJ1W4Q.text: Had lunch here with family, at the suggestion of my brother and sister in law.  I've walked by The Witchery many times on my visits to Scotland, but dismissed it as a likely tourist trap.  I was so wrong.   The atmosphere in the dining room was elegant.  Service was prompt, attentive and competent.    I opted for a three course lunch, starting with delicious Spanish charcuterie.  For my main course I indulged in a lovely wild mushroom risotto.  My meal was finished with a cheese plate.  All were very good.  Though in an area swarming with tourists, The Witchery is well respected by locals (such and my brother and sister in law).  I'm looking forward to my next visit.

ePk36YWy3X3BlpRB5wPKrg.text: Had 1130 reservations because that's all that was available. When we arrived, Place was pretty empty. Food and drink were good but not worth the price we paid. Settings was beautiful but tempered by nonplussed servers.

PCywHNeaNAQzu_eTe1-b7Q.text: We should have listened to the reviews. This place is definitely a tourist trap. The atmosphere is about the best and only thing going for this place. The service is terrible and the food was only mediocre. The best dish I had was the burrata and beet salad. Bread is cold and bland, scallops were far from good and the pumpkin lasagne was just okay. We didn't even get dessert because we were so turned off by the meal itself. Definitely not worth the money you pay here.

eLZrELceuiuMSBuo1l4k-w.text: We tried The Witchery on a recommendation from an Edinburgh local and we were thrilled that we tried them out.  The service was exceptional and the food was amazing.  We each ordered the three course lunch special so we could try different dishes, and everything we were served tasted amazing.  The Venison Tartare was seasoned very nicely and the Scottish Roast Beef was cooked just to my liking.  We will definitely be returning here the next time we visit Edinburgh.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Venison Tartare
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Scottish Roast Beef

9uXHQMQl6q1Iv_UIutWT9A.text: Food here was really good. Servers are professional and know the menu well. Went with the recommendation for the venison and I was not disappointed. The scotch they recommended went well with my meal and they will easily call a cab for you to be picked up.

7NTlQv7wfUcXLSssluPzOg.text: Fun for high tea. The price is high for a pot of tea and tower or treats but you are mostly paying for the experience, service, environment and high rent location. Worth a try if you have time and $$$.

OVbaqNb01KxfYtUduOC0TA.text: Rarely post and when I do it's for top ratings. We had done alot of research trying to find the most recommended places and this seemed like a sure thing for ambiance and meal and service. The ambiance was good - but that is about all.  Food was way over priced. If you are going to try this place eat before or after and get an appetizer or soup.   Service was slow and then when my steak arrived, it was still moo-ing.  They offered a new plate but I was so disappointed and not going to spend more time on bad service and over priced food. Was not handled properly at all. Manager terrible at customer service.

W6JK_o9NaNJ2ngANT4dxwA.text: I cannot say enough about how wonderful this place was! Our first trip to Scotland and my sister said we had to dine here. Each course was perfect and the wine was paired wondurfully.   A magical experience!

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

3beEkCLdtsvVav-a7-epUg.text: Nice welcome at the front desk... followed by twitchy, unpleasant table host, Andrew... made up by lovely waiter, Duggie. The table host is first unpleasant experience since we landed in Scotland. Everything else is going smoothly and we hope to shake off the table host attitude by the time we leave.

UQutSF10ix8cmIpU-yE3jw.text: The food was generally good but service only improved after I had to hint the waiter that things weren't going well. The audience is generally older, so I guess they didn't take a young single guy seriously or deemed good service necessary. No water refills, crumbs on the table, the waiter spilled my water on me and kind of thought it wasn't a big deal. Which is fine, but for a top restaurant and $100 lunch it was not a good experience.

UA8FXdg_19GKZeUXiTvpxA.text: This was one of our favorite stops in Edinburgh. Food, staff, service were Excellent. We had a combination of sea food and steaks, with very delightful deserts. The restaurant is located just below the Edinburgh Castle. Its a little pricey, but worth the extra, you pay. The inside decor is of old Scotland with murals and hand carvings on the walls, which make the dining experience that much more enjoyable.

nfHM2pEsEN59dRiLRNb3fQ.text: Last time we were in Scotland we saw this restaurant and wanted to eat here but could not get a table.  When we knew we were returning to Edinburgh we made reservations right away. We also chose the Secret Garden room.   Charming, quaint decor with helpful waiters. My steak was delicious. The 2 scoops of ice cream were very small but I really didn't need it to be larger but of course I wanted it to be.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Small scoops of vanilla and other orange marmalade
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Sides in cute copper pots
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Steak yummy

pA_R5-U-OxbefieucROiVg.text: We made our anniversary celebration dinner reservations here, based on a glowing recommendation by my Scottish colleague. Actually, I thought I had made the reservation at the Secret Garden part of the restaurant, but when we showed up, we were shown in to the main dining room, instead.  No matter, we were still awed by the view from the window (Edinburgh Castle, of course). Our waiter came hustling over right after we got settled, and went over the specials - including the tasting menu option - with us, before departing to give us a chance to look over the options.  Surprisingly enough, we decided to skip the tasting menu (I KNOW!) For my meal, I chose to start with the Roast Arran Beets, and the Cornish Bass for my main. My husband went with the Lobster Bisque for his starter, and the Caringorm Venison for his main. We paired our choices with a glass of wine, and chose to share the cheese platter for our dessert option.  I was very impressed by the food. The beet plate had a selection of different varieties, which was a good representation of how flavors can differ between varietals. My husband loved his lobster bisque (though he did say that it wasn't the best he's ever had). I was in love with the bass entree, though. It was perfectly made, and the flavor was incredible. The oxtail pot au feu - which originally made me cock an eyebrow - actually added a bit of depth to the dish. The sauces that finished off the dish were a nice addition, as well.  My husband rather enjoyed his venison meal, too. It was the first time either of us had seen black quinoa, but he said it tasted like regular quinoa to him. He certainly had no problems finishing off his dish.  The cheese plate was served with a couple of decaf lattes, and it all made for a nice ending to a wonderful meal.  The service within the restaurant was perfect - they were there when we needed them, but never hovered. They called a cab for us (because heels on cobblestone streets or on a downhill grade would have hurt me in so many ways), and kept us comfortable until it arrived.  The only thing that makes me sad about the night (other than the fact that we weren't in the Secret Garden, like I had requested) is that they never acknowledged our anniversary. I wasn't looking for sparklers and horns, but even a congratulations would have been nice.

XNtbQlacVNuy5F0w0a_ntw.text: The best lobster I've had in years. The service was amazing and the ambience was beyond wonderful. If I ever come back, this will be a must.

boGdTjjRLnsugeIAzjsUeg.text: Located in a historic sixteenth-century building at the gates of Edinburgh Castle. The Witchery creates a magical dining experience and although it is quite pricey it's worth it. The wine list is a giant old book - I've never seen anything like it. Offer post theatre menu which is brilliant value

Sur3EuZc3BL1lulrvps_zQ.text: Now I'm not against paying for good food, but I do feel that the Witchery borders on the too expensive at times. Saying that it has been around now for years so people clearly find it worth the expense. However I'm just not one of them. Nice setting but worth looking at the menu before going.

i26KMTN3jO8Wu-mXdSU6lw.text: Atmospheric lovers retreat. Sumptuous,stunning,quirky,all these sum up the Witchery. Star studded too as loads of well knwon stars have stayed here in the vast suites. Location is stunning adjacent to the Castle,well known restaurant,with stylish food,goodservice and a varied menu. A truly special place,for a special event.

iB7t_l3MK2uVnNctoeX4Xw.text: This is an amazing place to go. We went when we were visiting the city and will def go back when next in town. The service and food were great, we went for the pre theatre menu which was excellent value.

8QATBQy71EII5LhY57jzxw.text: having loved the tower in edinburgh we thought we would equally love the witchery! How wrong could we be. The service was good but not that friendly. The food was way overpriced as it didnt taste great and the portions were small. If you want a good view go during the day because at night you cant see a thing. Wont be going back, a major dissapointment.

tsxlG8NQZjqazRuyXB_GLg.text: I never go to the witchery on my own but I am invited about once a year. I went just last month and the service was appauling! The waiters seem like someone that would be working at an american chain, the sort that come to your table and say hello, my name is stephanie and I will be your server tonight. I had not noticed this in the past, must be cutting costs during the hard times. I was sitting close to the loo which is RIGHT in the dining area with the word TOILETS written on the door in plain sight of all the diners. Very classy. But apparently I was in very close to the stairs and in the way of the waiters who CONSTANTLY bumped into my chair and kept apologizing all night. Very unprofessional. When the waiter asked me how my dish was the only thing that come to mind was that the side dish, the veggies, were very nice with a nice butter and some seasoning and they were not over cooked which is typical of british veg. The waiter then asked how my fish was. I had not even thought about the fish when he first asked how my food was because it was so average and nothing special at all, my veg was more memorable. He seemed annoyed which just confirms my initial suspicion that the wait staff is very unprofessional and belong in TGI fridays more than a fine dining establishment. I saw that the witchery just won some award, cant remember the name, and its shocking! Yes, it is a beautiful place but what does that matter if the food is unmemorable and the wait staff just a joke? Says a lot about what people expect in this country when it comes to going out for a nice meal...

8B1UqEH7gYpPtDO5qRj5wA.text: fantastic food, wonderful unique rooms, very expensive but very very classy. great experience for a special occasion and edinburgh is brill too

Sb22FgiH6b04kSMFtGbUnw.text: Loved everything about this place!  Interiors -, it's like walking into a harry potter scene!  Food -, especially the risotto and asparagus for vegetarians!

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Outside
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Asparagus
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Interiors

ISvJbT-ErVHfA4JQcbzydw.text: We came here to celebrate a birthday on a Sunday afternoon. I reserved the table about a month out, but it didn't seem like I had to. It's a really neat place with a lot of history, but the only lowdown I got on it was from the website and the back of the menu. I really wish that they would do a better job of telling you about the place to turn your meal into an adventure. Instead we walked in and went straight to our seats without seeing very much of anything.   Once you're in (we sat in the original dining room), you feel like you're in a basement. It was about 21C outside and the restaurant radiates and somehow multiplies that heat by a factor of 2, it was uncomfortable as it heated up because I love my air conditioning. It was a relief to get outside after the meal.   I started with the steak tartare, which I usually love, but this was quite chewy and more of an exercise for my jaws than food for my tummy. I didn't finish it. My main meal was the ribeye steak, which was an elimination process of what I didn't want to eat. It came with crispy chips. It was ok, but I am more of a filet mignon meat person, I like super tender and melt in your mouth steak, which this was not, but it was ok.   We had a couple of beers, a couple of wines, and another meal and starter and the bill came out to 150. Super expensive for the food that we got, so be aware you're paying for the atmosphere and service mostly.   Our server was fantastic and I would give him 5 stars (Blair). The decor is great and we felt like we were in a very special and old place, I give it 5 stars. The atmosphere could've been better because the speaker was right above our head and the classic jazz, 1940's pop and blues they played completely did not match what your eyes took in. I suggest they play the Game of Thrones music on repeat instead of their current play list.   I also noticed that the menu on Yelp and the menu I had that day was quite different. There wasn't much that I was excited for when I was there, but online the menu helped sell me on this place so beware. Overall, it's average. I'm glad I tried it based on the history, but I'd never come back.

BdIPH9xpWM6s3BpEr7aixQ.text: Very enjoyable afternoon tea. We made reservation for around 15:00 or 16:00 on a weekday but didn't need one. The decor of this place (especially the entrance) is intriguing.  Scones along with their jam/clotted cream and macarons were absolutely delicious.   Another table near us was offered some history of the establishment by their waiter, which we didn't get but I wish we had.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Afternoon tea

CiTj9OHjS5s6wcDKMV-owA.text: The Witchery is a very unusual and interesting restaurant in Old Town near the castle in Edinburgh. There are lots of witchy statues and decorative items to look at. The restaurant set up is formal. Table cloths, fancy plates and cutlery. We missed lunch, but loved the dessert and champagne.  The Witchery is definitely worth a visit!  There is no shortage of things to look at.  A reservation is recommended.

Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

7cUB8bVXtJOIFzRP1r6jTA.text: After a long day of cold weather and tons of walking around touring the town the Witchery was highly recommended for dining. RSVP is needed and I think sitting in the main entrance dining area is best away from the door(just in case it's cold you don't want that draft). They have dining areas down the stairs from the host station. Did not know that till after dinner.   Service was good, but not great. I really enjoyed the food though. They charge for still water by the way so, don't be shocked at that. It was not a cheap dinner if you convert to USD lol.  I would go back again just for the delicious foie gras and sourdough bread!

wyUM3hHKBchnmsNCKtsFlw.text: A wonderful diversion from walking the castle and the mile. Had the lamb Wellington and haggas, both wonderful. Very professional waitstaff and a high end feel to the service. Large portions! Good to  share. Great wine list from around the world.

cuIGlvU96GTUQOJByXS9xg.text: I had one night in Edinburg and I had to come here after reading all about it. As far as scenic restaurants are concerned this was the right spot. It was very dark, red, & romantic. I thought the setting was just fabulous but a tad bit overpriced. I had the risotto and the buttered vegetables. Do not skip the risotto! It was a heavenly carbed plate. I enjoyed every last bite. The greens were a good balance for my tastes. I'm glad I came and experienced the beautiful setting. Keep in mind this is just an experience and not worth the price of the food unless you are only here for one night that is.

SKSKQTnfuRXnWG99AoANCQ.text: We found this place while searching for Scottish fare near Edinburgh Castle. The food is served in an upscale way, and we were able to enjoy Scottish flavors in an amazing setting. The seating area is dark and gloomy, which is very appropriate considering the medieval castle located up the hill.   I enjoyed the haggis with neeps and tatties. It was flavorful with a lovely spiciness. The lamb Wellington for two was presented beautifully and tasted delicious. We were pleasantly surprised to be served Glenlivet mineral water along with our meal. It went along well with the whisky theme of the Scottish leg of our Eurotrip.

iqJRfBOxKDkj5XRm09i8wg.text: Delicious fine dining experience in Edinburgh.  Top notch service and a nice menu with haute cuisine.  The wine list is extensive but they also have good wines by the glass.  The atmosphere is unique and interesting in itself.  I would highly recommend this place for a special occasion or fancy dinner.  Dress appropriately and make sure you have reservations at least a few days ahead of time.  Try to get the main dining room, although the garden area is worth it too.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

SFwdjmcwm6_JWYJSF8tE7w.text: We had an amazing evening here!!   Great food great staff great night!!   Stepping back into time. Next time I'm in town I will definitely be coming here again.

7R3d_X9pXB6xVQsBEhwaAQ.text: Very good. Excellent wait staff. Excellent wine selection. Excellent ambiance. Wish I had tried the lamb.

XKMRx6a4VCQgFe1MVKIqiQ.text: Wow, the Witchery will bewitch you. We ate at the original 400 year old location near the Castle where they once put hundreds of witches to death. It is dark, woody, elegant medieval candlelit romanticism with total  attention to detail from the menu, the extensive and incredible wine list and the decor. Think White linen tablecloths, napkins tied with red satin bows . Service was attentive and excellent in every way without being intrusive. We started with a cocktail and wine with a wonderful selection available. Next came their wonderful sourdough bread with creamery butter followed by fresh oysters, and a delicious pea veloute  with crispy bacon served with these crazy good little cheddar scones. For the entrees we enjoyed the scallop entree with crispy bacon & pea veloute sauce  and the venison with root vegetables and a small smear of mashed potatoes. The delicate sauce decoration was sublime. We added the roasted carrots which had  small dollops of yogurt sauce with cumin. No room for dessert but they have some good ones! Loved our evening here but trust me you Need A Reservation!!!  AND The other location right next door down the narrow pathway like the  "Secret Garden " looks amazing but we could not get in even with a three day window. Just Do it, dine here at the original Witchery, the secret garden or at their newer location (The Tower). You will not be disappointed while here in Edinburgh.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Romantic ambience
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The yum pea veloute with crispy bacon &amp; omg great cheddar scones!
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. The venison with root vegetables!

ARJjYSbNoh0BIQWpgAjbZg.text: 3.5 stars.  I get the Yelp rating for the Witchery but everyone kept ranting about it ( even the customs agent at Heathrow...yeah I have weird conversations).  So basically the food is Okay. Prices high.  The setting  and service are perfect. I especially found service to be spot on with apt timing and pleasantries.  All four of us opted for the pre-fixe  menu at 40  and it's not unreasonably priced. My first course was fine but felt very prefabricated hotel style.  The entrees were really good; excellent lamb, potato, and veggie.  The desserts save for the cheese plate felt very hotel premade.  Alas you come here for the setting and it's wonderful. Set in a 16th century house with dark and gothic accents it was fun.  Music selection is fantastic from Puccini to Celtic harp versions of U2 songs..I loved it.  Wine selection is insane here with a book listing 700 various bottles: anything from a 1992 Lafitte rothschild ( tipping in at a wallet busting 900) to lovely Malbec and Shirazs in the  30-40 range ( more my tier).  All in all come here expecting okay expensive food in an incredible surrounding with great service.

Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Lovely Malbec not too pricey

0xiLrm8eUUhwIEf8uyZyQA.text: The ambience was set as soon as you walked through the close. The theme was apparent yet not overdone at all. The Secret Garden has an intimate setting (good for small groups 4-5 people and dates), lavish velvety decor, and delicious food. The champagne, rose, and whiskey were refreshing. All of the dishes exceeded expectations:  - Curried pineapple chutney, swede, and potato bhaji (without haggis) - similar to an Indian style onion pakora, very nice of our server and the chef to make this vegetarian for us - Honey roast Arran beets with burrata  - Organic Phantassie farm mixed leaves  - Organic peas veloute with cheddar scones  - Foraged mushroom risotto with truffle oil  - Parmesan and tomato aubergine - Roast fillet of Scrabster cod  - Coconut tapioca for dessert. Nice finish! And also lactose-free.   Service was phenomenal! The hosts especially Oliver as well as the waiters including Paolo were so friendly, made great conversation, and were very helpful with local recommendations. Locals were also fond of this restaurant. Very memorable experience. Nect time I'm in Edinburgh, I would love to return here!

Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Stairwell into restaurant

ZelRQVyEy-_UIELEsA6mGA.text: Came here back in May for late lunch.  Staff is more professional than the touristy clientele that comes in so it feels out of place.  Food was good as well.  Not a witch in sight though!

YVKVDbNkggk2gmCOJr1q_g.text: I am so in love with this place! It was by far my favorite experience while in Scotland. We had a variety of food - lamb, haggis - but the standout dish was something we almost missed because we were quite full at the end of our meal - the orange chocolate flourless chocolate cake. This dessert made me wish I lived in Edinburgh so I could eat it every day.  The location is magical. It feels like you are royalty walking into a castle. While you are dining at the Witchery - you are treated like royalty from start to finish. Every dish we had was excellent. This is a place you can come to with family and friends or visit on a date night. I did see children dining as well, although I cannot speak to a kids menu. Honestly, I couldn't be happier with my visit.

yLD5Q8NXNvoUqNqSpe299g.text: We ordered steaks medium rare and they came out more on the well done side... "mash" potatoes could have had some more flavor and the chips were mediocre. Overall the atmosphere was great but food quality could've been better.

QRUQ1C2JFjNrLskfE28rNQ.text: Ate here twice, once for desert and once for dinner. Both experiences were excellent food with great service. The dinner was superb. We shared the lamb Wellington with three side dishes. The lamb was probably the best lamb I have eaten ever. It was tender, flavorful, and was perfectly prepared. The service was great and the wine selection recommended by the Sommelier was on target. The best meal I have had in Edinburgh.

w6w715PEmYKcdic3ASe1wQ.text: We had a pretty late reservation, 10pm, but it was worth the wait! The Lamb Wellington was cooked perfectly, and the staff was incredibly nice and helpful.

ZIauQYxd7X6upXOIloKJMg.text: Famous, upscale spot in Edinburgh. The ambiance is remarkable. Great for a celebration dinner! The wine selection was vast. We found a delicious bottle for 45. The scallops were slimy and undercooked. The Lamb Wellington meal for two was AMAZING!!!! I can't put into words how perfect it was.    The hostesses were very accommodating and friendly. The wait staff worked together extremely well and were very attentive. The Manager however had no personality. He was absolutely in the wrong profession!!!  If you have the extra money and want the experience of eating there, you will not be disappointed! If you're on the fence about it, skipping it wouldn't be the worst thing!

h0AR6VWewm_0B-4ReXM9sw.text: I've only been here once, my parents were meeting my boyfriend for the first time and I think they wanted to scare him! The atmosphere is amazing and you really feel special (then again, my Dad said that it was far from cheap!)

4iF2z1WGRb6369afwqY98A.text: Absolute Fantastic!The food was outsatnding and the service quick and friendly.it's a great little place with great history and elegance.The Passage way into the restaurant was beautiful and the all round presentation was superb!!

sWgrrKaSYZu8HeDVJ9jPlg.text: Negative 1. Overpriced 2. A bit over complicated menu, kinda hard to select your meal - you never quite know what you get :)  Positive 3. Very good location and Interior 4. Good service

ijaT3NTiamXc8vFAimCShA.text: Wonderful food, in a lovely setting. Great local produce used to prepare great dishes, presented without too much fuss. Service was great. The restaurant is beautiful too, old stone pillars and opulent decor, with plenty of nooks from which to watch other diners.

r7VMGS9ttxQEjE_QM463lw.text: Went for the pre-theatre menu, 12.95 for 2 courses, ended up having a desert too though because they looked so good. Best wine menu I think I have ever seen, although a bottle of wine I had the previous night somewhere else was 15 more expensive at the Witchery. We dined in the Garden Restaurant and it was lovely, really romantic, and I would recommend it to anyone looking for that real romantic dinner, a special occasion. It is very expensive though if you are dining a la carte so beware. Overall here, you are paying for the name of the place, the reputation, service and ambiance. The food is excellent but saying that, I didn't sample the full menu and I would say the food is secondary to the overall experience of it.

li8aOjdxJi39Ombo2blWcw.text: Branded as one of the best - if not the best - restaurants in the City. Well certainly the interiors live up to the expectations! Absolutely stunning! Walls covered in 17th century wood salvaged from the nerby StGiles Cathedral, comfortable furniture and just enough candlelight to make a romantic dinner perfect. What else? A lot of famous people visited and ate there - Michael Douglas, Cathrine Zeta-Jones, Matt Groening, Jacques Villneuve, Jack Nicholson and many others that I can't remeber right now! Moving on to the menu - the card changes every night but there are several positions to choose from, all made superbly to make you feel special. A vide range of wines and champagnes, plus many other things to drink.  But there are bound to be some minuses too: - service is very caring and active but looks a bit tired and more formal than friendly - no drink card (you have to ask about everything and dont see the prices before ordering) - very little space inside (table are squshed one next to another which doesnt make it very intimate) All in all worth of trying but be prepared to spend at least 50-60 pounds per person!

m60ThpIgBzsWVr0bkx7atQ.text: Big reputation and we left underwhelmed. The interior is gothic so dont complain about fustiness but food not better than many other less renowned eateries. We didnt eat inthe garden room so maybe thats why we didnt rate it. Have definitely had better food in better restaurants with less widley known reputations.

28f1_xcut8bkRmsu12OAxg.text: Amazing, amazing place and food Specially when it's cold outside!   Go there

yqd5LfmVOKti0F3ukTnOXg.text: The Witchery is a fantastic place to stay, with a small range of suites, each different to the others, but all beautifully designed (I don't think I've ever seen anywhere else do rooms quite like the Witchery). It's a wonderful retreat for a very romantic weekend. As other reviewers have said, the restaurant looks excellent but the food isn't fantastic - but is popular so perhaps there are plenty of people who disagree. Despite average food, the rooms alone deserve more than five stars.

cP9SdhgNPl6sVB15PF8Wuw.text: Went to the witchery last week and was disappointed with the food. I had the three little pigs which was basic bacon port burger and a pork chop. Very well cooked but very expensive and un inspiring for such a place   Service was excellent and the place is lovely. But if you put the food on it's own it would not be up to much.   Disappointed.

i8Mw3LcZXTNyFMsM1rhrlQ.text: I was taken to The Withchery for my birtday last year and i was very disapointed.The food was average,service was much the same,the only thing good was the setting.Although most people who are dining are their purly to be seen,not to enjoy a special night out like myself. Very Expensive for the quality of food and overall service.

bvVxBvPmV1EVd82hStvJIA.text: Beautiful place, like a hidden treasure chest and in a fantastic location on the royal mile. I went for lunch and I'm not going to lie it was expensive and there wasnt much on the plate so a bag of chips on the way home was what we needed but a place to try once in a lifetime!! The appeal for us was that in the guestbook lots of celebs had been there and we were made to feel like royalty!!

pw-14nJwt0ouZqH75brCrw.text: The Witchery is a great place for an office party, like a Christmas dinner, as the decent food and atmosphere get better with good company and a drink. It's certainly one of the most stunning decors in the Capital, but I'm not sure the food was that stunning. Still, worth a visit, though be prepared to be surrounded by cooing couples at most tables!

0rZnq3EQTjdZmaMGgXou8Q.text: Came here for lunch with family and very dis appointed. Service was average few things forgotten and when they came out they where so hot you had to wait to end of meal to eat them. As far as food goes very average and not worth the money. The Christmas lunch was particularly poor. The actual resteraunt was nice and relaxing but go to the number 1 at the balmoral!

ZYKMlOd7B8wqJXqXc8YUbg.text: Thought this restaurant was very over-rated. The location is very central if you're on the tourist trail and the decor has the wow factor - very gothic and brooding. BUT as previously mentioned, the staff are very snobby and I didn't feel comfortable. The food was nothing special, I wanted to order a side order of broccoli (priced at 3.95!) but they did not have any. I'm not sure if the wine list is meant to be a joke, but its thicker that War and Peace and pretty expensive (as is the a la carte menu). I wouldn't go back.

HvbuSTO-6XQGzXP4FhvGLg.text: Went for a meal with some friends in at the end of February and it was superb. The food was good and the service was fantastic, I will definately be back.

ndWxXv8cvBv2LmfL-oaWJQ.text: The Witchery is a great place to go for a nice or romantic meal. I sat in the main dining room. It was mostly lit with candles. The staff were friendly and in my opinion, not too attentive, as others have complained. I personally wouldn't consider the prices expensive, as many have. They offer a lunch/theatre menu for like 13 pounds and have a three course set menu for 30. I got a starter of soup for 7 and a main course for 15. My husband went for the seafood platter (35 pounds) and it was a ton of food. He couldn't even finish it. I would say you can make your meal here as expensive or as cheap as you want to. I also didn't find the portions to be extremely small. But, I have been to high end restaurants and knew what to expect. Overall, I would definitely go back to this restaurant for a special event. The atmosphere was romantic and serene and it was fun being at a restaurant where everyone was dressed up.

9BQN1VbO7JTs1kkAVVWG5A.text: The Witchety also has a 2nd restaraunts called "the secret garden", very exclusive but surroundings, service and food are excellent

AFKwVHS6MCUorUJANas-7Q.text: oh my word this has to be one of the best restaurants I have ever been to. Went on Halloween this year and I must give them credit, they could have packed the place many times over but they kept to their principles and the atmosphere inside was relaxed and calm. I have seen a few comments about the food being overpriced but as far as I am concerned you pay for what you get. don't give 5 stars often but the food, for me, was out of this world. highly recommend the venison accompanied by a nice smooth oakey red!

Seo-i3R5YxJpfgzpuL452A.text: been in during the day and the chap overseeing everything was extremely rude, wont be going there again and certainly won't be recommending the service. Food was good but you need the whole experience

QOj6XM1rqPpPvOpSBxla0g.text: I just didn't rate this place. I feel like I'm committing some sort of blasphemy by saying that, but when I came for lunch here it just wasn't that great.   Granted, we had a booking for 2pm, which is towards the end of a lunchtime shift and so the staff and chefs are all tired and a bit frazzled. But when you're paying Witchery prices, you don't really expect that to be an issue - if we'd wanted that we'd have gone to one of the million cheaper places to eat on the Royal Mile.  The portions were tiny, even by upmarket restaurant standards. However, I don't think this was down to them running out of stock - after speaking to other people who've eaten there it seems that that's just they way they do it here.  Which would have been fine, except mine was lukewarm. It was one of those puff pastry and roasted sun-dried tomato with goat's cheese type things that you get in most pubs these days, and the cold slimy tomatoes didn't really do much for me. In fact, it was probably quite a good thing that there wasn't much of it.  At least half of the pages in the menu are taken up by testimonials from celebrities writing about how they loved the place, followed by the Witchery's own epic autobiography, but I honestly think they'd do a lot better if they concentrated less on their image and more on what they're actually serving people.  I wouldn't rush back.

photos.caption: Photo of The Witchery By The Castle - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. image courtesy of www.thewitchery.com

-cClocx1f084cBOE5JyoHA.text: My husband and I had the pleasure of dining here in late April.  We had the lamb wellington and it quite simply was the best food I have ever had.  The staff treats you like royalty.  We were sat in the Secret Garden but the main house would be lovely too.  It is quite pricey if you are travelling from Canada or the US, as the pound is almost double to our dollar, but the experience was worth every penny.  Dress up!  This is an elegant restaurant to wine and dine in, not a laid back pub.

8haxQYVqCXr9oxXMbHAc_g.text: The name definitely denotes creepy but don't let that scare you. This fancy place requires some wait time but wait is worth. The food is extremely well prepared and the atmosphere is one of the best. This is a must if you're in the area.

lRXdZ8eCkv3KVocycTplAg.text: I came across this place online before my trip to Edinburgh. My husband and I wanted to have dinner for our anniversary. I was so excited to try it! The place is quite fabulous. We felt like kings and queens. I love the candle lit dinner and the food was quite delicious as well. We had champagne and a raw salmon appetizer with horseradish ice cream (didn't sound good to me, but gave it a try!). It was sooooo good. For dinner we had steak and venison which were both ok. I wish I would have tried something else. But, Overall I loved this place and feeling like I was dining in a castle. Dark, candle lit, and so cool!

C6MYBH5zo4CVKHigckSaQg.text: I have a hard time giving high-rated restaurants five stars, but The Witchery definitely deserved it! We had a large group of 13 and they not only were amazingly efficient, they knew everyone's wine preference by memory, had amazing food and were the nicest and most amenable staff for such a large group that I've seen. Hats off for great food, service, ambiance and overall dinner experience.

2HolZCxiY2kt3wDsZCHjOQ.text: I had read about The Witchery in all my guidebooks and after checking out their website I decided to splurge a little on our first night in Edinburgh-worth every penny!  We stayed in the Vestry suite which is the most gothic of all the suites and it was gorgeous!  Red velvet and gold line the walls, drape the windows, and cover the bed.  The bathroom has a huge, gorgeous tub, perfect for a long soak after walking around Edinburgh all day.  The staff is also amazing-they lugged our 50+ lb suitcases up 3 flights of stairs-I felt so bad but was definitely thankful after 10+ hours of travel!  We also showed up to a chilled bottle of champagne which was very exciting and an amazing way to start out our trip.  We only stayed here for 1 out of our 3 nights in Edinburgh because of the 295 per night price tag but like I said it was well worth it.  You absolutely cannot beat the location-we stayed here the first night and it was the perfect spot to help us get acquainted with the city-we could see the castle from our doorstep and the rest of the Royal Mile was right there at our feet.  You also get a continental type breakfast delivered to your room in the morning-the huge, buttery, chocolaty croissants were my fav!  Great experience-if you have a little extra to spend, definitely give The Witchery a try!

2J3sAFQXRaTIhvGk9wPvHw.text: A beautiful setting very close to Edinburgh Castle. I thought it would be very busy with tourists but it wasn't. We ended up going for the 3 course set menu which is very reasonably priced. The staters were great. Delicate and flavoursome. The main also matched this and the jus that came with the Glasgow Steak was incredible. The meat was a tad tough and the copper pot it was served in made it extremely difficult to cut into and eat from. Great dish to look at but I just wanted to get into it. As always I got the cheese board. Nice range of cheese also sourcing locally where they could. Even though we had 3 courses we didn't leave full. The dishes tended to be on the small size. Also the service was attentive to start but maybe inexperienced as when our drinks came to the end we never got asked if we would like another. Not too much of a big deal as it was the middle of the day and we didn't want to drink that much. (Visit - 02/01/2015 Lunch)

sLwYpB-ue4FVr1RR_XyKUQ.text: Save your money. I had fairly high expectations as I heard this was a place for fine food and I had been in Scotland for 10 days with all excellent food. I ordered the fixed price 3 course for 35 pounds.  My starter was red mullet on cucumbers with potato salad. The potato salad was mediocre at best and I didn't finish the mullet. I enjoyed my roast chicken main but given that it was called pot roast on the menu I expected potatoes and carrots... A roast of some kind... Dessert was a dry pistachio cake that lacked a theme between that and the rhubarb stalk laying next to it. My 3 girlfriends had the same experience... One not even finishing her main. The service was bad in that they were completely absent. When they were available it was ok....but overall Serious lack of attention making it the worst service at this price point I've ever experienced.  I had some excellent meals in Scotland but this was the worst $60 USD I've ever spent-ever. I would take it back if I could. Save your money.

sJ4cS1TrbFHXKwrBkKsZWA.text: We ate here last month. It was eye-wateringly expensive, there is little vegetarian choice, and not only is there no children's menu but they would not condescend to make our 5-year-old anything that was not on the menu. For the price point (60 a head) this was below average.

dHnfKf9pM747-O6RtQ79-g.text: Not only superb food but wonderful Room as well! Staff is attentive and helpful, it's a place to feel at home
